title: Kilmainham Brooch
text:
The Kilmainham Brooch is a late 8th- or early 9th-century <a href="Celtic%20brooch">Celtic brooch</a> of the "penannular" type (i.e. its ring does not fully close or is incomplete). With a diameter of 9.67 cm, it is a relatively large example, and is made from silver, gold and glass, with <a href="filigree">filigree</a> and <a href="Interlace%20%28art%29">interlace</a> decorations. Like other high-quality brooches of its class, it was probably intended to fasten <a href="cope">cope</a>s and other vestments rather than for everyday wear, as its precious metal content would have made it a status symbol for its owner; less expensive Viking-style brooches were typically worn in pairs on women's clothing. 
The brooch is dated to the late 8th or early 9th century based on its 8th-century design patterns, along with the fact that silver was not easily available in Ireland until the first <a href="Early%20Scandinavian%20Dublin">Viking invasion</a> in AD 795. It was found in the 18th century during an excavation of a Viking burial place in <a href="Kilmainham">Kilmainham</a>, on the fringe of the city of <a href="Dublin">Dublin</a> in Ireland. Although established as being of Irish origin, its form and decorations seem heavily influenced by both <a href="Viking%20art">Viking art</a> (in material) and earlier <a href="Picts%23Art">Pictish metalwork</a> (in design and technique). It is held at the <a href="Kildare%20Street">Kildare Street</a>, Dublin, branch of the <a href="National%20Museum%20of%20Ireland%20%E2%80%93%20Archaeology">National Museum of Ireland</a>, where it is on permanent display in the "Treasury room".
Description.
The brooch is classed as <a href="Penannular%20ring">penannular</a> as its ring is incomplete (does not fully close). It is made from gold, silver and (mostly red) glass and <a href="Vitreous%20enamel">enamel</a>, and is similar in form and material to the better-known <a href="Tara%20Brooch">Tara</a> and <a href="Hunterston%20Brooch">Hunterston Brooch</a>s.
The frame is of cast-silver and contains cells that once held gold spiral <a href="filigree">filigree</a> and glass inserts, although some of these are now lost. The ring is outlined by double ridges in <a href="Reliefs%23High%20relief">high relief</a>, with flat areas reserved for decorative elements. Its top contains a wide oval compartment or cell bearing traces of red enamel, while the sides are formed from gold plates bounded by twisted wires and <a href="interlace%20%28art%29">interlace</a> decorations. The ring ends on two quadrilobate terminals (ie consisting of four lobes each), which are formed from a central square surrounded by semi-circular or crescent lobes, three of which are free, while the fourth is shaped and attached to arm of the ring itself. The format of the quartrefoil terminals has been compared to the opening folio for the <a href="Gospel%20of%20Luke">Gospel of Luke</a> in the c. AD 800 <a href="Book%20of%20Kells">Book of Kells</a>. The overall head is strap-like when viewed in cross-section. 
The <a href="tracery">tracery</a> on the curves of the ring is made up of <a href="Interlace%20%28art%29">interlaced</a> bodies and legs of <a href="Zoomorphism">zoomorphic</a> animals, including an <a href="Irish%20elk">Irish elk</a>. Most of the original pin head is lost with only its base remaining intact, and also has traces of red enamel. The reverse is mostly flat, but repeats the shape of the oval compartment on the front. It has some interlace designs, including two interlocking dogs.
The brooch's style has been described as of "<a href="Ecclesia%20%28ancient%20Greece%29">Ecclesia</a>-<a href="Gothic%20art">Gothio</a> character" with "fine workmanship", and compared to the Tara example although "not so fine". Although described in 1989 as "probably Irish", it contains structural and decorative designs, including its lobed (ie "hanging") terminals, small cusps, and the <a href="Cartouche%20%28design%29">cartouche</a> on the hoop, are reminiscent of the <a href="Picts%23Art">Pictish-syle</a>, indicating that it may be of <a href="Northumbria">Northumbria</a>n origin (unlikely), or at least heavily influenced by that style.
Brooches of this type are the most common and thus studied form of surviving Irish and Scottish medieval metalworks, due both to their then popularity and inherent durability. Examples such as the Kilmainham Brooch were built by skilled craftsmen and their workshops using precious metal, and intended as status symbols for wealthy (and often female) commissioners.
Dating.
The Kilmainham Brooch is usually dated to the late 8th or early 9th centuries as it is seen as transitional in both style and material. Its annular form and use of filigree place it in the 8th century Irish tradition, while its use of silver, as opposed to <a href="gilding">gilding</a>, indicates at earliest an early 9th century origin, that is in the period after the 795 AD <a href="History%20of%20Ireland%20%28800%E2%80%931169%29">Viking invasions of Ireland</a> , when silver became more available to native metalworkers.
Provenance.
It was found in the mid-18th century at a late 9th- and early 10th-century <a href="Viking">Viking</a> burial site at <a href="Kilmainham">Kilmainham</a>, <a href="County%20Dublin">County Dublin</a>, Ireland, alongside <a href="sword">sword</a>s and other artifacts of Scandinavian origin or influence. After further excavations in the 21st century, the area of Kilmainham-<a href="Islandbridge">Islandbridge</a> was described by historian Stephen Harrison as "demonstrably the largest burial complex of its type in western Europe, Scandinavia excluded".
The find spot was near the ruins of a late-medieval hospice run by the Saint John of Jerusalem <a href="Knights%20Templars">Order of Templars</a>. Its earliest recorded ownership dates to the late 18th century, when it was in the collection of Ralph Ouseley of <a href="County%20Sligo">County Sligo</a>. Today it is held by the archeology branch of the <a href="National%20Museum%20of%20Ireland%20%E2%80%93%20Archaeology">National Museum of Ireland</a> on <a href="Kildare%20Street">Kildare Street</a>, Dublin, having been acquired by the <a href="Royal%20Irish%20Academy">Royal Irish Academy</a> before 1853.
Replicas.
The mid-19th century copy in <a href="Victoria%20and%20Albert%20Museum">Victoria and Albert Museum</a>, London, is from George Waterhouse, a jeweller from <a href="Sheffield">Sheffield</a>, England, who moved to Dublin in 1842, and exhibited the Tara and Kilmainham Brooches, and their replicas, at the 1851 <a href="Great%20Exhibition">Great Exhibition</a> (or "Crystal Palace Exhibition"). An early 20th-century bronze and <a href="Gilding">gilt</a> replica is in the <a href="Metropolitan%20Museum%20of%20Art">Metropolitan Museum of Art</a>, New York. Both were produced during the <a href="Celtic%20Revival">Celtic Revival</a> when there was high demand for replicas of objects from Ireland's medieval period, particularly from its "Golden Age of Irish Art", roughly AD 700–1200 (especially for metalwork).
Replicas of the brooch were given the "celebrity" title of the "Knight Templar" Brooch to increase saleability as nationalistic <a href="shawl">shawl</a>-pins (a naming trend also evident in the titling of the Tara Brooch, which was in reality found from the <a href="Hill%20of%20Tara">Hill of Tara</a>, but was at times named the "Royal Tara Brooch". <a href="Adolf%20Mahr">Adolf Mahr</a> later dismissed the trend for giving brooches —and more importantly their replicas— such titles as "fanciful... and sometimes ridiculous... by a firm of Dublin jewellers". The V&A acquired its copy at the 1851 Exhibition.
